vision.notes: Based on the description of stripes on Thylacinus cynocephalus (Tasmanian tiger) and its ecological role as a predator, vision was likely an important sense for prey detection and navigation.

olfaction.notes: As carnivorous marsupials related to other members of Dasyuromorphia, olfaction was likely important for hunting, social communication, and possibly navigation. The description of the thylacine as resembling a canid further suggests a reliance on smell.

audition.notes: Audition was likely important for detecting prey and conspecifics. While specific auditory ranges are unknown, a general mammalian hearing range is inferred.

touch.notes: Tactile sensation via whiskers (vibrissae) and skin receptors would have been important for navigation, prey detection, and social interaction.

taste.notes: Taste is likely present for assessing food quality, although specific details are unknown. As a hypercarnivore this modality would have been functional.
